print_settings.Notes:: The insert plate must be printed with UV sensitive filament, in order for the colour changing mechanism to work.

description.text:
Sometime ago when I'm studying high school physics I'm fascinated with the idea of radiation dosimeter badges. Always think they look cool :P

Yesterday I got my hands on some UV sensitive filament that will change its colour when exposed to a UV source (e.g.: Sun). So I designed this little badge that changes colour when exposed to sunlight.

The case is printed from PLA so doesn't matter which colour you like. Just find a nice leather cord to hang it with. The middle insert is printed with UV sensitive filament. When exposed to sun light it changes to purple. The middle part (circle) got the largest area so it will change first. The sun flares (triangles) got smaller exposing area and obstructed by PLA. Usually it won't change colour/minimal changes. But when it started to change its colour it means sun light is strong enough to pass through the PLA layer (obstructing area). You know it's time to put on some sunscreen then.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

The insert plate must be printed with UV sensitive filament, in order for the colour changing mechanism to work.

250 ml Erlenmeyer flask

You can set nut size in two different ways:

description.text: Toppen till hydroponiken

This is just a simple clip to keep a seatbelt clip in place.
Build with support as this does have an arc to it to place less stress on the plastic. I have printed this in PLA and it works really well. The slender plastic arms only bend slightly which is an improvement over other clips that I have seen.

** Revision 2
After using the first version I noticed some issues. The "arms" tended to bend out more than I thought they should so I increased the "gap" by 1mm and shorted the arms too make it easier to install and remove from the seatbelt.

** Revision 3
Increased the width of the "arms" to strengthen them slightly.

description.text:
Hey Guys,

just a simple eccentric spacer ( 6 mm ) which is compatible for OpenBuilds plates. The thinner section may or may not print on your setup - but that isn`t a problem. It is made for M5 screws.

Printer:

Custom Core XY

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm should do well

Infill:

100% for stability reasons

Notes:

Pretty easy to print - proper cooling and slow speed should do the trick.

Clean up the print as usual and adjust hole size with a drill or so. Tolerances are quite tight on this part (actual zero tolerances on diameters and hole sizes - printed well on my setup without need of post processing).

I needed a new full switch plate with a switch guard to replace the broken one in my garage that controls my furnace power. I had problems with warping at the corners for the first few attempts so I added break-away "mouse ears" to the corners and they seemed to do the trick for my most recent print.

I printed with ABS, .5 mm nozzle, .4 mm layers, Cura settings for "Touching Buildplate" support and "None" platform adhesion type, 100% infill.

The support had to be cleared from the hollow inside of the part but for me it wasn't too bad other than leaving a rough inner surface.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4 mm

Infill:

100%

I used MS 3D Builder and merged a modified section of the "Light switch Safety Guard" thing with the SwitchPlate file of the "Coverplate Generator" thing and then fabbed up "mouse ears" at the corners with a thin separation section between the ears and the part to allow them to break away but fuse well enough to stop warping.
This is a project I did for a request I hope it turns out well.

title: Solidoodle 4 X-Motor Cable Guide and Fan Shroud

description.text: Cables tend to run over work surface, disrupting work in progress. Also, X motor gets extremely hot. This cable guide keeps the cables off the work surface. 40mmx12mm fan snaps into shroud from below, shroud snaps onto X-motor. You can use a cable tie to hold it in place, but it was not necessary on mine. .STL contains 16 links for the cable chain, though you will probably only need 12-13, so there's a couple extras. Endpoint attaches to electronics cover with a screw, or you can just drill a hole in the cover and use a cable tie. Original .RSDOC (DesignSpark Mechanical) file included so you can modify if necessary. You will need to turn motor 180 degrees so cable comes out the opposite side. NOTE stock cable may not be long enough...you may need to splice on some extra length.

Days of wondering though the icy tundra have left you tired and frozen. Fingers numb, ears and nose burning from frostbite, this could be the end. Then though a part in the snow you see the glimmer of a warm camp fire. A mirage? A trap? It seems to good to be true and your wisdom is high enough to know it probably is. But the flickering flames beckon to you. Your body moves with it's own will towards the warmth. Just as you draw closes enough to feel the heat warming your frozen face, the ground starts to rumble. Fangs burst from the ice all around you. With luck you jump clear, as a giant white woolly beast emerges from the snow and stares you down.
Roll for initiative.

Note: Thanks to the "fur" this is an insanely large file. It crashed my computer twice trying to print so download with caution. Also the teeth turned out to be a pain so it might be necessary to cut the teeth out of the print and add in the teeth printed from the separate files. They might require some scaling and hand carving to make them fit. Hope you enjoy.

title: Convertion frame from QX90 to diy 2s tiny whoop

description.text:
This is for converting a QX90 to a 2s tinywhoop style quad. The props needs to be cut down to size, using a compass and a nail clipper is what I found to be the easiest way to do that. The solder bead on the fc needs to be moved from "1s" to "2s". The camera needs to run off of just one cell. What I did is that I took a 2s balance plug and soldered the outermost pins directly to the board and the middle pin to the positive of the camera. The cameras negative cable can be soldered to ground wherever. The QX90 top plate and standoffs act as bottom plate and battery holder on this frame. The camera and battery are held on by rubber bands and the fc and rx are held in place either by just friction or a dab of glue. Heat shrink tubing can be placed around the motors to act as landing feet to protect the battery wires. The motor mounts needs to be carved a little bit larger to fit the motors.

Flies well with a 2s 200mAh-350mAh battery.

If the "elephant foot" isn't removed the quad might make a loud whistling noise.

This quad is a few mm larger than a standard inductrix, so it will NOT fit most cases

description.text: This is a three part Braille cube. The components, which snap together, can be rotated such that the dot combinations can form all Braille characters. It may be useful to teach people who do not have ready access to Braille books.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Finest resolution possible (0.2mm)

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Solid fill is best but it also works with a sparse fill.

Assembly instructions
  1. Line up all three pieces in a row such that all the dots are on the same sides (e.g. the double dot sides are facing you, the empty sides are on the left and one of the single dot sides is on the right. Maintain the relative positions of these faces as you assemble the cube.
  2. Slide the middle piece (the one with the hole through the middle of it) onto the shaft of the base piece.
  3. Slide the top piece onto the top of the cap until it clicks into place.
  4. Give it away and make another one!
Assembled Braille Cube

The Braille cube: an inclusive integrative project This small Braille cube is quick to print out, and so can be used as a quick demonstration of 3D printing in a STEM design class. It is also a useful tool to teach anybody, sighted or otherwise, how to identify and read individual characters in Braille (both grade 1 and grade 2 characters).

description.text:
This is a redrawn socket adapter for opening a water meter box, using the concept from pillthomas. This adapter will fit 13/16" (.8125" point to base) pentagonal bolts commonly used on water meter boxes and it fits a 1-1/8" socket.

There are three files - the base one is designed to be slightly larger for the bolt opening as I found mine had swollen with corrosion a bit and the "proper" size was a little too tight. The "exact dimension" file is the tight fit, so adjust if needed to fit for your uses.

edit 2/27/17 - I've added the "largest adapter" file, which opens up the bolt opening a hair bit more and makes for the best fit on my meter.

A few months ago I had this T-Rex made out of lasercut .090 Aluminum for my son (He calls his T-Rex "Dino")and I figured this would be a good 3D print as well.  I was correct.. :-)
"Dino" will make a great desktop companion or an awesome gift for a 8+ child. (8+ includes grown men like myself... Ha!)

All that is uploaded thus far is the .STL file of the complete assembly, which is ready to print with no assembly required. I will be uploading the 26 individual T-Rex parts as .STL files as soon as I get around to it so that you can assemble your "Dino" on your own for much more added fun. The picture that I have uploaded is of the .090 Aluminum model that I made. My first attempt at printing the plastic model didn't go very well as I scaled the model down to far and the plastic was REALLY thin. I will upload a picture of the plastic model as soon as the support material is removed. PHOTO UPDATE
I have provided a photo of the 3D Printed "Dino" along witht he .090 Aluminum model.

description.text:
I made this direct driven ball valve to control the flow of steam out of my DIY boiler, it acts like a proportional valve.
This design is more compact and easy to build than geared ball valves.
I used a 1/4 NPT 304L stainless steel ball valve (you can find some on the web for 5 euros), and it's driven by a MG996R servo.
The program used on the Uno is "Knob" from the servo library.
I think it can be improved, feel free to comment.
Happy printing!

print_settings.Notes:: For the chamber, please use a floor thickness of at least 0.9mm and the 20% infill. Otherwise you may have holes in your floors.

description.text:
This is version 2 of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1367219 with lots of improvements:

UPDATE V2.1

I uploaded three new files: Chamber, Base and Cover. With these, you can stick the Chamber inside the Base. If you've already printed the Chamber V2.0, cut the little "L"'s on the sides off. Now it should fit in the new Base.

V 2.0
  • all parts should now fit nicely together, without filing (or at least much less filing)
  • the acrylic fits now in place by an holding mechanism (btw ignore the hole in the acrylic in the pictures, it's the acrylic from version 1)
  • no more need for an metal grid / netting glued under the chamber part
  • the holes at the base are now bigger to let the water flow more easily

Theoretically the grid size is 1x1mm, but in print it's much smaller (at least on my printer). Please watch your printer printing the first layers, if you think the grid is too big, please leave me a comment and i will upload a version with a smaller grid.
 
If you find this useful, tips via Paypal are appreciated ;)

Text from version 1:

The design is inspired by the antscanada.com ant nests. Unfortunatly the shipping costs to my country are way to high, so i designed my own formicarium for my Camponotus herculeanus ants.
You can put some cotton in the base piece, stick the chamber on top of it and water the base piece from both sides (there are little holes in the walls), to regulate the humidity.

The entrance blocks are for 12/16mm aquarium tubes. I separeted them, so you can design your own entrance blocks. Or if something break, you don't have to print the entire formicarium again.

You need a sheet of 2mm (acrylic-) glass.

Printer:

MigBot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the chamber, please use a floor thickness of at least 0.9mm and the 20% infill. Otherwise you may have holes in your floors.

comments.text: What nozzle size did you use to get the grid in the chamber to work? I'm using a 0.4mm nozzle and all I can get is a grid of unconnected dots from the slicer (Simplify3D). Is there some other setting I need to be aware of to make this work?
comments.author: ianlee74

comments.text: I was getting the same thing using Simplify3D (series of unconnected Squiggles). I think with Simplify3D the retraction is faster then the nozzle movement so the corners are not completed. I retied the same model with Cura and the grid came out fine. For the Chamber I would try reducing the retraction speed or just use Cura for that part. Good Luck

I wanted to create simple garden fence.
I usually just weld recycled steel bars , but it looks ugly, requires painting if fence is expected to resist rust and so on. So here is alternative design - it uses cheap threaded rods from hardware store, which are zinc coated and usually resist few years outside without rusting. They can also be painted or covered with linseed oil lacquer. i've used roses i've found on thingiverse as decoration, but one can put anything on top really - i also snap example with "autodesk head" and stalin snapped on top . provided blender file if anyone wants to create own custom holder. objects are merged togeter via boolean transform and just before export to stl just click on 'master' object (like rose) from which all transforms stem from - object will be exported with all holes OK then. one hole should not be tapped but drilled with 5mm drill - as it's impossible to 'close' fence otherwise (or one would require left-sided thread on last holder). after putting rod there is small hole on the side to secure it with set-screw. EDIT:
i've added openscad version.
it is much simpler, and you 'close' the fence by drilling through one hole , and just using ordinary nuts on the threaded rod to capture it.

you need to tap holes after printing.
m5 is used for 90 degree joints, and i also threw one rose which has just straight holder for 10mm rods - for larger fences. side holes are for securing rod in holder which is 'closing' fence,
you need to thread just the one you use as closer (i.ve provided holes everywhere so it's easier to recycle holders) after installation it's good to paint the rods even though they are zinced - i.e. with linseed oil lacqueer or acrylic.

title: Airsoft G36 to M4 Mag Adapter

description.text: Made a mag adapter for airsoft G36 and SL9 to work with M4 magazines. Print with supports enabled. There shouldn't be any support structure in the feed tube.The support structure around the mag release can be difficult to remove, don't cut the pivot point on the release and do not insert a mag until you get the release to move. The file with the U should work with Umarex and the one with JGTM should work with JG or TM compatible, they're both close but have minor differences that mess with bb feeding. I tested them on a Umarex SL9 and a JG G36K.

title: MPCNC Bosch Quick Release & Vacuum Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
5/22/2017
I fixed my problem with the vac connection & made it part of the quick disconnect. I am pretty happy with it now. I ran a 1.5 hour cutting job with no problems. I also got rid of the slanted cut for the top of the router mount as it did not seem necessary and also allows you to rotate the router the way you want it.

3/18/2017
Looks like I need to shorten the height of the bottom vac attachment. Don't know how I missed this, but the bottom of the vac piece is too low unless you have a long router bit. I will revisit this design next week to see if I can shorten it the correct amount. Meanwhile, I have deleted the bottom vac attachment from this design.

I started updating my vacuum connection recently for the MPCNC that I have after finding this interesting idea for a dust shoe. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:200583 After remixing it, I realized I could make this in 1 part instead of 2 & print it without supports. About the time I finished doing this, I came across a quick release mount for the Bosch, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:648883 I initially did not see that someone else had remixed this to work on a MPCNC. The original design worked pretty good without any alterations. The major changes I made to the quick release design were to make the 2 cams only 1 part & made the cam about 1mm longer with a flat part of cam to hit the arm which held it in place better for me. That wider flat part where it hits the arm made a big difference in having a snap fit. You can hear this snap in the video I uploaded. Using a wider cam instead of the 2 smaller cams also made this connection more solid. For the 2 part mount I added the 10 degree slant cut to fit the Bosch rather than having it even at the top. If you do not want that, you can comment it out in the openscad file.

This is for the original 3/4" EMT MPCNC. I did make an option for the newer C-525 version, but that will be an untested version until someone else tries it.
I uploaded a 37 second video (previous design) of how this mounts together. https://youtu.be/sbKFyQ6KR_E

After completing the quick release modification, I had to change my vacuum attachment so it would not hit the quick release when taking the router off. That turned out to be fairly easy to fix by making sure the vacuum duct was below the bottom of the mount & adding an angled adapter for the vacuum. I do loose about 1.5" of cutting length along the Y-axis. If you do end up needing that extra 1.5" of cutting on the Y for some project, you can just disconnect the vacuum attachment for those cuts.

I included STL & openscad source files. The Mount & Arm quick disconnect I made 2 versions of. Make sure if you print the X-Axis or Y-Axis version of one, you print the same of the other. There are 2 versions in case you care which axis you loose some space from the vac connection. If you need clarification of which to use, take a look at:

BoschMountAssembly_Rev36.scad file & set the variable:
Vac_Orient = 0; //0 = along X-Axis, 1 = along Y-Axis

STL files to print:

BoschMount_X-Axis_Rev36.stl (50% to 60% infill)
or
BoschMount_Y-Axis_Rev36.stl (50% to 60% infill)
armWithVac_X-Axis_rev36.stl (50% to 60% infill)
or
armWithVac_Y-Axis_rev36.stl (50% to 60% infill)
Latch__2x_Rev20.stl (50% to 60% infill)
Pins_3x_Rev21.stl (50% to 60% infill)
cam_Rev24.stl (50% to 60% infill)
Vac_Adapter_32_8Ang_Rev20.stl (20% infill)

Optional parts to print:

If you need the tool holder nut & drilling guide for this configuration, I included the STL files:
Tool_Holder_Nut_Trap_x2_76_2mm_28mm_rev1.stl
Zpipe_DrillGuide_rev5_x2_76_2mm_28mm.stl

There is also an image showing the nut trap spacing for further clarification.

I printed most of the parts in eSun PETG, but did print the bottom vacuum connection & adapter in PLA.

In addition to the Vac_Adapter_32_8Ang_Rev20.stl that puts the vacuum hose vertical, I added a 30, 45 & 57.3 Angle adapter to use at different angles. The 57.3 should put the angle horizontal. I have not seen anyone connect the vacuum hose horizontal at the tool mount & might not be a good idea, but thought it might be worth experimenting with since this would keep from loosing any cutting distance along the Y-axis.

I included the openscad source files along the STL files. The profiles for the vertical 3/4" EMT connections are in a DXF file which should make it easier to adjust for another EMT size.

comments.text: It should be possible to make an adapter for the RT0700C to fit with this design, but not sure about adapting the whole thing to fit the HicWiC Mount. You can make a simple Test adapter to see if the adapter would work by opening the customizer for https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2520982 & changing the ID = 65 & the Cham_Ang = 0. Also change the Ht = 6 or whatever height you want to use for a test print. After printing that fit it on your RT0700C & see if it feels strong enough. The diameter of the opening for this quick release is 70.70mm which is not easily changable. That only gives you 2.85mm of plastic around it, but that probably is enough since it is used inside the main mount. I took a look at adding the HicWic mount to this, but would take a bit of effort & not sure how well it would work. The openscad source files are there if you want to try it yourself.

There is an option for that in the openscad file BoschMount_Rev36.scad
Type = 0; //0 = Old, 1 = 525C
Depending on whether you set Type = 0 or 1 the program will use the Old or 525C profile from the VerticalPipeConnect_Profiles_Rev120.dxf file. This is untested, so you may have to tweak the dxf profile some.

comments.text: GeoDave, Nice Design. The long black extension pipe will put a lot of torque on the gantry as the vacuum hose is moved around. It acts like a big lever arm. This Thing is an extension of the dice that won't roll off the table in:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2126472
To minimize friction, an M5 spacer is inserted at the right side of the rotating elements.
https://youtu.be/hExGP_J3mc8

As a wheelchair-user i often need to overcome a step in front of a building, a shop, cafe or bar. Therefor i had the idea of printing me my own small ramp. It has to be as small as possible to carry it in my bag, when i'm on my way through Berlin.  
This is my first prototype. Please feel free to print and to develop it... Any feedback is apreciated!

10% infill  
Takes more or less 26(!) hours to print.

remixed_from.author: ra99gt
remixed_from.title: LulzBot Mini Spool Bushing, 56mm ID X 70mm Length

title: LulzBot Mini, Ball Bearing Spool Adapter

description.text:
This is a remix of my adapter bushing for 56 mm ID x 70 mm width spools, which fits on the stock spool arm of the LulzBot Mini. I modified the adapter to use (4) 10 x 15 x 4 mm ball bearings (the diff bearings from the Team Associated RC10 B5m/T5m RC car). I also removed as much of the extra material as I could, to reduce the printing time.

This adapter should fit 65 mm wide spools with an inner diameter of 47 mm to 60 mm, but I've only tried it with 56 mm and 57 mm ID spools.

I've also added the .STEP file, so you can modify the bosses and adapter to work with your own bearings and spools. But, don't make the bosses for the bearing too small of a diameter, or they may crack from the weight of the spool. You also want the bearings to fit tight on the bosses, so the inner race of the bearing doesn't spin, only the outer race should spin. Good luck!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.38 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used 30% infill to support the weight of a full spool. I haven't noticed the bosses cracking so far :)

I printed my adapter in ABS, with the stop tab side on the print bed (180³ from the orientation shown in the Thingiview window), so no supports are needed. The bearing cut out around the boss is short enough to bridge over.

Check fit of the bearings!

I sized the bosses to fit my particular set of bearings so the inner race press fits onto the bosses and would not spin. If the fit is too tight, the bosses can be sanded, but the enclosed bosses will be difficult to get to. If the bearings are loose, the inner bearing race can be carefully superglued to the bosses.

description.text:
NEED:

  • Need to put laptop right in front of my drum set

PROBLEM:

  • Drum need to place close to a wall
  • Can't drill / mount things on wall
  • Require portability, able to move around easily.

SOLUTION:

  • Tripod with a plate of some sort to hold laptop, make one of the tripod leg shorter so the stand can put as close to the wall as possible.

End up I search on Thingiverse and found the one and only one tripod assembly http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423897, design by JuliaTruchsess. The size and structure is perfect and it even have pointy feet for carpet ! Grab the VESA mount plate made by imaicom and remix it a tiny little bit and design the pole mount, the whole package is there. Some wood work to cut out a wooden plate to hold the laptop and Bob is your uncle.

As for the tripod, you probably see I get one tripod leg shorter, that's is just to make it able to put the tripod as close to the wall as possible, for my own need. Nothing was change from Julia's design, so I didn't include it in here. You can just refer back to JuliaTruchsess thingiverse design (link above) for the whole instruction and STL file.

NOTE:

Since I use the laptop mainly for drum, I ain't going to rest my palm on it nor use the keyboard that often. ie. no weight is going to put on the front of the laptop, so I don't foresee the pole mount going to loose grip causing the plate to drop to the front and finding my laptop on the floor. Having said that, your usage may vary, please consider that before printing this as this is like a 24 hours print job and some wood, bolts and nuts purchase.

UPDATE:

The stand has been placed in front of the drum for roughly eight month, still holding strong, no dipping, no adjustment made and holding my Compaq 17" laptop perfectly. Pretty much the only keys I'll touch is the POWER and ESC button 99% of the time. I'm gaining confidence on this stand, giving it does swing a tiny bit when I type, mostly because of 1) it's on a thick carpet, 2) the laptop is consider heavy with 6.8lbs on top of the center post which is 39" long and most important 3) because I shorten 1 leg for my own requirement.

Infill:

75% PLA for the plate and pole mount

Instructions
  • Print out Julia's tripod design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423897, assemble the tripod to your need (height, angle... etc)
  • Print out the 2 x STL file here, the pole mount fit right onto the top of the center post.
  • cut out the appropriate size of material (in my case - wood) to hold your size of laptop
  • mount the plate.stl to the material you cut out (do pay attention to the weight distribution of the laptop, mine was a 17" screen unit and with the screen open most of the time, the weight is lean towards the back for the laptop, thus I mount the plate slightly towards the back, check out the side view photo.)
  • apply some caulking silicone around the mounting hole on the plate (you'll see some indent space made for that), this is meant for friction purposes and also use it as a semi glue effect. So I can tilt it or take it apart easily and not glue tight, yet gave me friction that the plate won't just drop.
  • mount the plate on top of pole mount and tighten up the nuts and bolt, if I remember correctly the bolt should be 5/16 x 3".

description.text:
BT 80 nose cones, includes a model with PeaNut altimeter mounting embedded. Elliptical, conical and ogive nose cones.

Best printed in ABS or PET-G for their superior impact resistance and temperature stability.

Can be printed with minimum infill (like 3%) or using Simplify3D print the bottom part with no top or bottom and print the very top with 4 top and bottom layers and moderate infill (50%). I also use a lower layer thickness at the top.

Built in altimeter mount requires S3D in order to have a hollow body.

I modified this part to add cooling channels for additional breathing room around the V6. I added tapered holes for the MP Select with a slightly larger base mounting post. I modified the front clamp to fit a 2-in-1 style E3D V6 Fan Duct.

Added base with extra 1.5mm for larger (Official) E3D Heatsinks. This is labeled as "ZeroOffset_Bracket_Official_E3d.stl"

I recommend PETG, ePC or ePA-CF with 100% Infill

description.text:
Very adjustable and strong tap handle.

The wheel shape makes it very easy to use especially for small taps. Holding it upright with one finger of one hand and turning the wheel with the other hand makes it easy to get the threat perfectly aligned.

The handle can take taps up to 5mm diameter. The taps are locked and released with the nut while the hex flange bolt is held straight by the hex shaped grove on the outside.

You also need:
2x M5x20 screws with hex key
1x M5x20 hex flange bolt
1x M5 nut

Initially this was just a proof of concept. I was interested if it is possible to create an tap handle with exchangeable taps that is able to lock the tap thigh enough to use it practically.

I achieved this goal by creating an notch with two bolts and pushing the shaft of the tap in this notch with an other bolt.

Printer:

Sintron Prusa i3

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%
Prewarm the hex key scrwes and run them in. The hex flange bolt is to be fitted in the hex grove on the opposite side.

I'm a middle school technology teacher. Unfortunately I've had my SolidWorks 20 license dongle go missing before. When I got my new one I whipped up this protective shield for it. It is fastened to the computer case with two M3x16 screws leftover from the Makerbot. It has two nuts inside the case to prevent easy removal.

comments.text: My head is spinning, an open source object protecting proprietary software's copy protection. I perfectly understand why you would do this, yet it seems awkward at the same time. A dongle is a physical item for the foremost reason that software can be duplicated with more ease than physical objects. Yet this is becoming less and less sharp a distinction.
comments.author: Erik

comments.text: Cool idea  - and cleanly done.  Could probably add a lot of strength by dropping all but one vent slit on each side.
comments.author: Bophoto

comments.text: Hey, that's a nice idea. Is the material strong enough to put up some resistance, or is it more about the "haha, I took his usb-stick!" - factor in the school?
comments.author: feroxx

comments.text: I'm not too worried about someone taking it. It had been there for 3-4 years before it went missing and it happened when I was out for an extended period of time. However, this thing is pretty sturdy. I'm not saying that you couldn't break it off if you really tried, but if you grab it and try to bend it any it doesn't budge. Also by being black it blends in with the computer so it doesn't really say, "Hey, try to mess with me!"

description.text:
Magic The Gathering 60 card deck box that slots together and looks like a library and a graveyard when taken apart.

On the library, I added some windows to the sides and extended them up so that the cards wouldn't fall out the side.

For the graveyard I made the sides a little thicker so they would be more durable, as well as changed the design of the fence to be easier to print.

For both sides I made the floors solid as I was having trouble with the box flexing a lot when they were see through. It should be a pretty good friction fit on both halves, but I have been putting a rubber band around it just incase.

title: Raspberry PI camera mount/support and lens hood

description.text:
Failed to find any suitable support for a Raspberry PI camera for one of my projects, so I designed this one. It mounts on the inside of a box with two screws, where the camera PCB is held by its outer edges.   
There is also a camera lens hood that attaches to the other side of the wall. The interesting trick here is to use a cheap slide for microscope for the glass window if you need it to be waterproof, sealed with silicon. Because of this, be careful to print the lens hood on its top (check the geometry)!
I printed it in Nylon to keep it flexible. You may have to adjust the tolerances in the source code but it should be OK (or use a drop of silicon glue, eg.).

print_settings.Notes:: See section below on inserting magnets while printing.

description.text:
This is a modification of the GoPro Sketching Stand that I created earlier to add LED lights to illuminate the drawing. See a video of it here and here.

Materials

  1. GoPro Camera and included mounting bracket (tested with Hero5 Session)
  2. 3 1/8"x1/8" x 12" steel-plated rods
  3. #5 metric hex nut that fits GoPro mounting screw
  4. Battery case with switch that fits 2 AA batteries
  5. 2 11mm wide LED lights
  6. 12" each of black and red electrical wiring (single thread)
  7. Heat-shrink tubing
  8. Soldering iron and solder
  9. 3 8mmx3mm Neodymium Disc Magnets Super Magnets 07045
  10. 2 AAA batteries

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

Standard

Notes:

See section below on inserting magnets while printing.

1. Bend 2 of the steel rods 90° at 6"
  2. Cut 3rd steel rod to 8.25"
    . Thread the red and black wiring into holes that go into the center of the bracket.
  3. Insert the first LED light into a seat and solder red and black wires to its leads (red to longer wire, black to shorter wire). Trim LED leads
  4. Insert second LED light into other seat and wire short length of wire to leads from first LED to second LED, matching the red to long lead, and black to short lead. Solder and trim connections.
  5. Thread wires through heat-shrink tubing and heat tubing to shrink it.
  6. Thread cable mounts onto heat shring tubing
  7. Thread cut metal rod through cable mounts and into square socket in GoPro bracket.
  8. Thread 2 1" lengths of heat-shring tubing on leads from battery pack.
  9. Cut and solder leads from battery pack to wires from camera mount assembly.
  10. Place mount top on top of wiring
  11. Insert rod from camera and bent rods into stand.
  12. Slide battery back (with batteries) into stand.
  13. Insert GoPro camera into housing mount.

    Optional LED Tally light

  14. Print the top model with the hole in the center
  15. Solder an additional LED light to the wiring to add an additional tally light that will light up on top of the mount when on.

    Final steps

  16. Secure top mount with a zip-tie
  17. Follow GoPro settings instructions below to setup your GoPro camera.
Mount assembly Stand assembly Finished stand

The metal rods stay in the base assembly with magnets that need to be inserted in the model while the print is in progress.
While printing, you will need to pause the printing at two points to insert the magnets. You do not want the magnets to protrude over the print layer as they might hit the print head.

  1. When the center is about to be covered (~7.2mm)
  2. When the side mounts are about to be covered (~10.5mm)

Most print heads are not attracted to the magnets, but if your print head is, you may need to glue the magnets in place before continuing the print after pausing.

The 3MF files with the base geometry are included (*.geometry.3mf) if you want to change the models.

  1. Open the *.geometry.3mf files in Microsoft 3D Builder on Windows 10
  2. Modify the basic shapes models
  3. Save the model as .3MF
  4. Create a New scene in 3D builder
  5. Insert the *.geometry.3mf file into the scene
  6. Subtract and merge shapes as necessary to create the final models.
  7. Save the model as .3MF or .stl
Resize the purple elements to change the size of magnets before subtracting from green and blue base assembly.

Configure the GoPro Settings using a GoPro mobile App
  • Video Field of View (FOV): Linear
  • Auto-Rotation: Down

description.text:
I designed an RC10B5m rear sway bar bracket to replace the stock molded bracket, which spit in half, while tightening the mounting screw. Doh! Of course you can't just buy a replacement bracket, only the entire kit :( So I made a 3D printed version!

There are 3 sizes of the brackets to work with the 3 different bar sizes in the rear swaybar kit, 1.4 mm, 1.3 mm, and 1.2 mm. Each bracket is sized such that there is little slop between the bar and the bracket. Print 2 copies of each size for a full set of brackets to work with all 3 bar sizes from the rear sway bar kit!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Keep the same sizes bracket together on the print bed, then bag them in pairs, to keep them separated.

Clearance the hole

You might need to open the diameter of the mounting hole a little so the screw will go though or you can just thread the screw though the bracket and into the rear shock tower.

A thin wall of different heights surrounds the flat section of the bracket. This wall keeps the bracket from spinning, locates it on the rear shock tower, and reduces the space between the sway bar and bracket, so the distance the bar can move front to back is minimized, but the bar can still rotate freely.
